  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: When package was unloaded off trailer a very small amount of liquid squirted from the puncture. From there the drum was placed into a hazmat bag and then into drum. DescribePack: small puncture next to the rim of the lid DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: non combustible material was used to clean up the small spill. Metal drum was then placed into a hazmat drum

item.title: Report X-2023080424
item.description:
Report X-2023080424

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-16T18:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-03
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Chicago Central and Pacific Railroad
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 08-03-2023 A CN mechanical performing an inbound inspection of train L-57191-03 observed liquid dripping from the bottom outlet valve cap of tank car # UTLX 212943 along with a strong Ethanol type odor in the area. The employee notified the Yard Coordinator who in turn made internal emergency notifications per the CN ERP. The tank car was set out to an isolation track (WA90) for inspection by the CN Dangerous Goods Officer. A CN Dangerous Goods Officer responding to the incident. It was immediately noted upon the initial visual inspection that the BOV handle was in the "engaged" position and the BOV handle was not pinned. It was also noted that there was wetness around the threads of the BOV cap with wetness on the ballast directly below. An Ethanol type odor was also present. The BOV cap was found to be less than tool tight (could turn by hand) allowing any product collecting within the cap to leak out. Several attempts were made to dis-engage the BOV handle from the valve so it could be pinned in the closed position. These attempts were un-successful. The BOV cap was then removed to determine if the BOV was still leaking as the tank car did not drip any liquids during the DGO's inspection and attempts to dis-engage the BOV handle from the valve. Although there was standing liquid within the BOV cap, the valve itself did not leak after a 20 minute observation. The cap was then re-installed tool tight. A cable seal was utilized to secure the BOV handle in the closed (9 O'clock) position so that it may not open during transit. Home Shop decals were applied to both sides of the tank car, the BOV was red tagged (do not operate). Both the shipper and consignee were notified of the incident and were advised the tank car will require an FRA OTMA 1 prior to being released.
